name: Maldives
description: The Maldives, officially the Republic of Maldives, is a tropical nation in the Indian Ocean, southwest of India and Sri Lanka. It’s an archipelago of 1,192 islands, grouped into 26 atolls. Known for its stunning coral reefs, turquoise waters, and luxurious resorts, the Maldives is a premier destination for diving, snorkeling, and relaxation. The country faces significant challenges due to rising sea levels and climate change, making conservation efforts crucial for its survival.

quickFacts.label: Population
quickFacts.description: The population of the Maldives is primarily concentrated on the inhabited islands.
quickFacts.detail: Most Maldivians live on the 199 islands that are part of the local council system.

quickFacts.label: Area
quickFacts.description: The Maldives is one of the smallest countries in the world.
quickFacts.detail: It’s comprised of 26 coral atolls, each with a unique ecosystem.

quickFacts.label: Capital
quickFacts.description: Malé is the bustling capital and commercial center of the Maldives.
quickFacts.detail: It’s the most densely populated island in the world.

quickFacts.label: Currency
quickFacts.description: The official currency of the Maldives.
quickFacts.detail: US dollars are widely accepted in tourist areas.

quickFacts.label: Official Language
quickFacts.description: The national language of the Maldives.
quickFacts.detail: It’s derived from Sinhala and Arabic.

quickFacts.label: GDP
quickFacts.description: The economy is largely dependent on tourism and fishing.
quickFacts.detail: Tourism contributes approximately 30% of the GDP.

climateData.title: Tropical Climate
climateData.description: The Maldives enjoys a tropical monsoon climate characterized by consistently high temperatures and humidity throughout the year. Rainfall is concentrated during the southwest monsoon (May to November) and the northeast monsoon (December to April).

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Dry Season (November - April)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: This is the peak tourist season, offering sunny skies, calm seas, and low humidity. It’s ideal for diving, snorkeling, and watersports.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Wet Season (May - October)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: The wet season brings increased rainfall and stronger winds. However, the seas remain warm, and prices for accommodation are generally lower.

naturalWonders.name: Baa Atoll
naturalWonders.description: Baa Atoll is a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve renowned for its exceptional biodiversity and vibrant coral reefs. It’s a haven for marine life, including manta rays, whale sharks, and sea turtles.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The atoll boasts the Hanifaru Bay, a feeding ground for manta rays during the southwest monsoon, attracting divers and snorkelers from around the world. The coral reefs are incredibly diverse and healthy, supporting a wide range of fish species.

naturalWonders.name: Rainbow Reef
naturalWonders.description: Rainbow Reef is one of the largest single-piece coral reefs in the world, located off the coast of North Malé Atoll. Its vibrant colors and diverse marine life make it a spectacular underwater destination.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The reef’s unique formation and the abundance of coral species create a kaleidoscope of colors, hence its name. It’s a popular spot for scuba diving and snorkeling, offering opportunities to encounter a variety of fish, turtles, and reef sharks.
viewingTips: Maintain a safe distance from marine life

ecosystemData.title: Maldivian Ecosystems
ecosystemData.overview: The Maldives’ ecosystem is primarily defined by its coral reefs, which support a vast array of marine life. The islands themselves are composed of coral, limestone, and sand, creating a unique terrestrial environment. The country’s delicate balance is increasingly threatened by climate change and human activities.

biodiversityCategories.name: Coral Reefs
biodiversityCategories.description: The foundation of the Maldivian ecosystem, providing habitat for countless marine species.

statistics.details: Over 300 different coral species thrive in the Maldivian waters.
Approximately 1,000 fish species inhabit the coral reefs.

notableSpecies.name: Manta Ray
notableSpecies.significance: A keystone species in the reef ecosystem.

notableSpecies.name: Whale Shark
notableSpecies.significance: The largest fish in the ocean, a majestic sight for divers.

biodiversityCategories.name: Seagrass Beds
biodiversityCategories.description: These underwater meadows provide crucial habitat for juvenile fish and invertebrates.

statistics.details: Seagrass beds cover approximately 100 square kilometers of the Maldives.

notableSpecies.name: Green Sea Turtle
notableSpecies.significance: A vital component of the seagrass ecosystem.
